text:
<!everyone> hey folks!
a few quick updates on this slack channel:
• please post any/all requests for quotes/surveys/data in <#CKRJX5U5A|collab> regardless of the topic.
• i think we should keep beginner level questions out of <#CJ7QQKJ73|-content-strategy-questions>. we'll kindly remove any that we see and suggest resources for that member.
• <#CTF6SG2GP|mgmt-and-ops> is the new home for content ops, people management, hiring and DEI.
• the old ask-me-anything channel is now <#C014P2BJLER|general>. if you don't know where else to post, start there.
• i updated our community guidelines. (see attached screenshot)
we'll be moderating this more tightly. if we ask you to move your post, know that it's only to keep this place tidy. thank you all!
---
okay, a few cool things for you:
• we're doing a web3 AMA with <@U01AHL8AGBB> next week. if you have a question you'd like answered, please DM me ahead of time. you can add this to your calendar there → <https://calndr.link/event/ZApCzctzh1>
• we have a guest post from <@U035FFGEHT2> → <https://superpath.co/blog/freelance-content-business|How to Properly Set Up Your Freelance Content Business>
• and we also have a new $100k Club :moneybag: post up :money_mouth_face: → <https://superpath.co/blog/director-of-content-earning-170000year|Director of Content earning $170,000/year (plus profit sharing)>
and lastly, here are few great threads from the past few days:
• <@U036K0S6AQJ> → <https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/CJ7QJ4WKB/p1647256812654019|Do you think there is demand for freelance content strategists/consultants/managers who don't write? And do you have any tips for getting started?>
• Yours truly → <https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/C014P2BJLER/p1647270001124109|Curious how folks are feeling about heading back to the office. anyone work for a company that's having employees come back?>
• <@U02Q67WK4LS> → <https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/CUYDAGXKR/p1646683426844369|How have you onboarded a writer to someone's voice and perspective they'll be ghostwriting for?>
• <@U02MKHPD7CJ> → <https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/C014P2BJLER/p1646843189087709|I work for a B2B sales tech company and am looking to add a social media management tool to our stack. Does anyone have any recommendations?>
• <@U0211K6LSM9> send me a DM and we'll send you an audiobook credit for this <https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/CUYDAGXKR/p1646692090598139?thread_ts=1646683426.844369&cid=CUYDAGXKR|fantastic response>!
have a great week folks!
:v: jimmy

text: thanks for doing this! I think this kind of moderation and clarity can help keep all the channels more valuable for everyone :blush:

elements.text: thanks for doing this! I think this kind of moderation and clarity can help keep all the channels more valuable for everyone

text:
Feels a bit ick to share this but I think it will be genuinely useful to people who are new to Slack (or not new but don't use threads).

This is a thread (right here where you're reading now :wave: ).

I am the biggest advocate of threads in Slack for all the reasons Jimmy mentioned (and many more).

Instead of making this a wall of text, I have neat blog post for newbies: <https://dispatch.m.io/slack-threads/>

attachments.fallback: News about Slack, Microsoft Teams, Webex & Team Collaboration: Slack Threads: Best Friend Or Arch Enemy?
attachments.text: Slack threads are a lifesaver to productivity and notification fatigue - BUT ONLY IF YOU USE THEM CORRECTLY. Help is on its way :blush:
attachments.title: Slack Threads: Best Friend Or Arch Enemy?
attachments.service_name: News about Slack, Microsoft Teams, Webex & Team Collaboration

text: why remove beginners' questions? beginner content strategy is content strategy too! seems unfriendly to junior-level folks who are trying to break into the industry, who sometimes are coming from underrepresented or intentionally excluded backgrounds already, so why exclude them more? -- just my $0.02

elements.text: why remove beginners' questions? beginner content strategy is content strategy too! seems unfriendly to junior-level folks who are trying to break into the industry, who sometimes are coming from underrepresented or intentionally excluded backgrounds already, so why exclude them more? -- just my $0.02

text: <@U01FUP6AMEZ> my goal is keep questions like "how many words should this blog post be?" or "i'm a crowded market, what should i do?" out of that channel. perhaps i should rephrase to be more specific. we want thoughtful questions. if you can google it and easily find the answer, then don't post it.

elements.text: my goal is keep questions like "how many words should this blog post be?" or "i'm a crowded market, what should i do?" out of that channel. perhaps i should rephrase to be more specific. we want thoughtful questions. if you can google it and easily find the answer, then don't post it.

text: my hope is that the <#CJ7QQKJ73|-content-strategy-questions> channel is really rich. challenging, interesting problems and helpful responses. and as you point out, that's not exactly the same thing as "no beginner level" questions

LOL

text: hmm, i can see why that is valuable from a moderation perspective, but not as a community member. new and "green" perspectives are often enlightening, ESPECIALLY on old-hat questions some of us have debated to death already. our industry is constantly evolving, and rarely objective, so the answer to "how long should a blog post be" won't always be the same -- so asking it different ways over time will yield surprising and educational new answers. isn't that the whole point of a learning community? i promise i won't die on this hill -- it's just that my inclusivity red flags go up when i see a gate or fence installed around any kind of knowledge, or forcing a community member to go dig around for answers when they might just prefer to hear from someone instead

elements.text: hmm, i can see why that is valuable from a moderation perspective, but not as a community member. new and "green" perspectives are often enlightening, ESPECIALLY on old-hat questions some of us have debated to death already. our industry is constantly evolving, and rarely objective, so the answer to "how long should a blog post be" won't always be the same -- so asking it different ways over time will yield surprising and educational new answers. isn't that the whole point of a learning community? i promise i won't die on this hill -- it's just that my inclusivity red flags go up when i see a gate or fence installed around any kind of knowledge, or forcing a community member to go dig around for answers when they might just prefer to hear from someone instead

text: Perhaps another channel specifically for those kind of beginner questions? Ones that could be answered quickly and concisely by more advanced members of the community, and once they find their feet they can move to the #content-strategy-questions channel where the more advanced/thoughtful questions could live? Just a suggestion, I can see where both sides are coming from :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Perhaps another channel specifically for those kind of beginner questions? Ones that could be answered quickly and concisely by more advanced members of the community, and once they find their feet they can move to the #content-strategy-questions channel where the more advanced/thoughtful questions could live? Just a suggestion, I can see where both sides are coming from

text: i like that, but also think that kind of separates "beginners" and "advanced" content marketers into two intellectual classes...when really, the most advanced person in here may be really garbage at navigating certain new algo updates where a more "junior" person would know lots more! I guess my point is that there's no such thing as truly "advanced" in a field where the targets move every day anyway, so the restriction may actually kill dialogue that I'd find valuable as a member.

I guess my point is that there's no such thing as truly "advanced" in a field where the targets move every day anyway, so the restriction may actually kill dialogue that I'd find valuable as a member.

text: <@U01FUP6AMEZ> this is great feedback. i'll give this some thought. i think it's important to foster "advanced" convos (tho its admittedly hard to define that) but the last thing i want to do is exclude anyone. will let it marinate and come up with a plan!

elements.text: this is great feedback. i'll give this some thought. i think it's important to foster "advanced" convos (tho its admittedly hard to define that) but the last thing i want to do is exclude anyone. will let it marinate and come up with a plan!
